remixed_from.title: Philips Hue - double Hue remote UK light-switch cover

title: Philips Hue - single Hue remote UK triple light-switch cover

description.text:
This is designed to cover a UK light switch (up to triple switch) and hold a single Philips Hue dimmer remote control. The original light switch is still accessible when the Hue remote is removed.

I did this as a quick modification of my double-hue switch cover, when my triple light switch turned out to be a bit too wide and deep for the otherwise excellent switch cover I had bought from cgcrute's collection available on eBay.

For the magnet, I chose to use the same as cgcrute used for his switch covers:
http://www.banggood.com/50pcs-N52-Super-Strong-Disc-Magnets-20mm-x-3mm-Rare-Earth-Neodymium-Magnets-p-997169.html

Chris (cgcrute / chriscrute) does a great selection of switch covers at a good price, so I'd advise most people to buy from his eBay range if you can:
http://www.ebay.co.uk/itm/Philips-Hue-Dimmer-Remote-UK-Light-Switch-Adapter-Cover-/253183690339

7-Oct-2017: updated photos from latest print. Increased thickness on front plate does improve the look (original design & print was a bit thin from the front through to the rocker-switch aperture inside). Model online was already updated for this on 3-Oct-2017.

description.text: Yet another fidget spinner. this time pentagonal and loaded up with 20 off UK 2 pence pieces (4 coins at each of the five points).

Notes:

The files used to create and debug the coinholders and bearing holder are also included, but all you need to print are Spinner5, Spinner5_Rings and FidgetSpinnerButton.

Gluing the parts together

Once the spinner is printed and the coins in place, the rings are "glued" on top of the coins with a few drops of acetone. The buttons should press-fit nicely in place into the bearings.

Bearings are 22mm OD, 8mm ID, 7mm deep.

If you want to reprint it for different coins or different bearings, I've included all the component parts which I needed to add, subtract and merge in 3D Builder.

Scanned with the MakerBot Digitizer Desktop 3D Scanner

It was a school woodshop project

Just a simple hex shelf for placing stuff on top, and bottom.

Size:
Length about 140mm (5.5 in)
Depth about 60mm (2.36 in)
Height about 44.5mm (1.75in)

A lot of the dimensions being a result of making from the center to the point of the hexagons 22mm.

remixed_from.author: Crunch3D
remixed_from.title: Prusa i3 MK2S No Mod Cable Chain Kit - Remix X Axis Mount

title: Prusa i3 MK2S No Mod Cable Chain Kit - Remix (longer) X Axis Mount

description.text:
I'm was using parts as this X-axis mount https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2311596
but not the same Rambo case (chain coming out on the other/right side of the USB connection) and the cable chain required the longer mount but it is a bit to long and also sometimes touches the Rambo case when printing to close to the edge.

Then I found the remix i remixed this from https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2496035 but it's to short so I remixed the two to create a longer version that is about one cable link shorter than the long but same mount for the screw as the remixed version.

Also took the liberty to slightly increase the zip tie holes on the top as my zip-ties only fit the lower holes and added two more in the middle of to secure the cables. Also took the top "fin" from thing 2311596 to reinforce to compensate for the bigger/extra zip-tie holes.

Printer Brand:

Prusa

Printer:

i3 MK2S

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.15

Infill:

100%

Notes:

EDIT 2017-10-27: I have now mounted and tested it, works great for me with the nylon filament keeping the mount away from the Rambo case.
All cables are routed on the side not facing the Rambo case.

100% infill might be overkill but rather have it strong, test/final print in E3D EDGE, printed slow and it feels sturdy, other PETG should be fine (my old one was"normal" PETG.)

remixed_from.author: pheneeny
remixed_from.title: AM8 - Metal Frame for Anet A8

title: AM8 - Z and Y endstop holders with tighter holes

description.text:
Modified endstop holders for AM8

These parts are the same as provided by pheneeny, but the diameter of the mounting holes for the micro switches has been decreased.

The Z switch holder

My Anet A8 uses 2x16 "wood screws" to fix the Z-switch. But the original design uses a diameter of 2.50mm for the mounting holes. So my 2mm screw felt through. :( The new diameter for the switch holes ist 1.50mm.

The Y rod holder

The original Y rod holder uses 1.75mm diameters for the switch holes. Due to printing tolerances my 2mm screws are somewhat loose. The new diameter for the switch holes is 1.50mm.

Printer:

Anet A8

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2mm

Infill:

60%

Notes:

Please print all the Y rod holders in a horizontal way. That means, that the both 5.2mm holes must be vertically aligned to the bed. And please use a shell, a top and bottom layer of at least 1,2mm. This will prevent the object from being fractured when tightened to the aluminium frame!

description.text:
This is a modification of Emmett's excellent Preassembled Iris Box. I've made the following changes:

  • Extend the internal tabs to prevent the outer shell from lifting up when the box is closed. This lets you pick up the box when closed without worrying that the leaves will fall out of the top pegs.
  • Add support at the interface between the base and the outer shell. This makes printing easier as the outer shell isn't printed on air anymore, but this has to be cut in post processing (see photos)
  • Remove the sharp base and replace it with a much more rounded one that's easier on the hands.
  • Increase the thickness of the bottom of the box to make it sturdier.

The HQ STL file was generated with the sphere resolution set to 160, the other STL is at 120.

Printer Brand:

Ultimaker

Printer:

Ultimaker 2

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.1

Infill:

50%

Carefully cut out the supports with a hobby knife, then sand the interior smooth so that the outer shell can turn freely.

Be careful with trying to force the leaves open the first time, my test print had one leaf stuck and I ended up breaking one of the internal pieces trying to get it to close. To unstick my leaf, I inserted a painting trowel between the leaves and the inner/outer shell. Then once I got the leaves to close a bit, pulling on them from the top helped. Another technique I tried was pushing on the leaves from the bottom, or using a screw driver pushing on them sideways through the narrow slit.

Opening and closing the box multiple times smooths it out a bit. You could then apply grease to improve the motion if desired.

description.text:
It's time for a siesta!

But not for me! I keep working on more countryball models!
Spainball is the next one in my countryball series. My girlfriend is studying in Cordóba now so I made this figure for her as a gift. This little guy got a moody look and the crown from the Spanish flag, a bit oversized for his head. Maybe that's why the moody look. :)

EDIT (2017.10.08.): Updated the bottom part. The connections were a bit messed up.
EDIT (2017.10.12.): Sorry everyone! At first I accidentally uploaded the clips of the Betyár countryball instead. I fixed it now.

Printer Brand:

Ultimaker

Printer:

Ultimaker 2

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.15 mm

Infill:

20%

Notes:

This model is designed to be printed in multiple parts, WITHOUT support. Since the eyes are separate pieces you can print the tree layers in the colors of your country's flag. For the best accuracy print it slow! I've used 20 mm/s for the outer walls. Print two of the clips and crown clips.

Assebbly

The model is designd to be assembled without glue only with its snap-fit joints. Check out the video! ;)
https://youtu.be/osLqe4-cGMw

Note that the tolerances were designed to fit the accuracy of my Ultimaker 2. You will need a similarly accurate printer and fine settings for the snap-fit joints to work properly, otherwise you might have to readjust the size of the clips.

author: DanielJosvai

description.text:
OpenOcular began as a project in college which looked to add the benefit of digital microscopes in the classroom. This tool allows any smartphone to capture images directly from the microscope or telescope ocular lens.

To setup, secure smartphone onto clamp and align camera within the slot. Then fasten adapter onto ocular. Loosen smartphone clamp to move camera along slot however, ensure you are holding phone before loosening clamp.

This tool is still evolving over time so your feedback would be a huge help. Check back for more updates!

The adapter was designed using 50% infill and at .3 mm resolution.
For best results, print laying objects on print bed as shown

This file comes from a 3D scan of a pumpkin created with an Artec Spider and processed in Autodesk Meshmixer. For best results print at high resolution, ideally in excess of 100 microns.

print_settings.Notes:: The only issue I had come while trying to upload files onto this page. The bottom piece and the 4 rockets printed as one piece, but Thingiverse won't let me upload the assembly. You'll notice (if you download it) that the rockets have a lot of random construction lines in them. When you print, make sure to mate the rockets and bottom piece so that they each stick out at a 45 degree angle, and suppress the assembly so the printing program treats it like a part, so it can print all at once.

description.text:
Snowball is the cute little robot that floats behind the Overwatch hero Mei, spraying snow everywhere, and generally being a happy little sidekick. I recreated Snowball in Solidworks, making the head, body, rockets, and wing flaps all separately, then assembling the rockets and body together, and eventually printing each piece in a Makerbot Replicator 2X.

Enjoy! :)

Printer Brand:

MakerBot

Printer:

MakerBot Replicator 2X

Rafts:

Yes

Supports:

No

Notes:

The only issue I had come while trying to upload files onto this page. The bottom piece and the 4 rockets printed as one piece, but Thingiverse won't let me upload the assembly. You'll notice (if you download it) that the rockets have a lot of random construction lines in them. When you print, make sure to mate the rockets and bottom piece so that they each stick out at a 45 degree angle, and suppress the assembly so the printing program treats it like a part, so it can print all at once.

description.text: These two parts stem from a 3D scan of a pumpkin, created with the Artec Spider and processed in Autodesk Meshmixer. The "pumpkin full" file prints as one object on one extruder, while the "pumpkin body solid" and "pumpkin stem solid" allow for duel extrusion. Print in high resolution for best results

My first day flying in real life resulted in me having to repair my VTX antenna 3 separate times.

I'm sure that I'll get better with practice but in the meantime I'd like to reduce the amount of soldering that I have to perform in the field.

So I designed this rear mount for an SMA pigtail that angles the antenna up and away from the frame and the props. When printed with Taulman SemiFlex it's stiff enough to keep the antenna in place but yields enough to absorb a fair amount of force in a crash.

This is my first uploaded design, I hope somebody else can find this as useful as I have.

description.text:
Came across these interesting High Intensity Cree LED White Strobe Light for Drones and decided to design a carrier for the DJI Spark (other versions coming). This bracket mounts to third party landing gear (http://amzn.to/2fP8YCp I highly recommend getting this landing gear even if you don't print this!).

As you can see the bracket is attached to the landing gear by two zip-strips (one on each leg) and third hold the strobe unit in the bracket.

Also check out this video we made on the attachment and use of this bracket with the DJI Spark here on YouTube at https://youtu.be/Uhbaw1Ti_P8

Note: These things are selling fast so I also linked 3 & 5 packs which also found on eBay too as well as some tri-color options:

On Amazon:
http://amzn.to/2ynm2pU

On eBay:
https://goo.gl/LXGiua
https://goo.gl/kgtNwo

OneBay (single tri-color):
https://goo.gl/qwVKob
https://goo.gl/j8xm8T

Also check this page out for regular updates:
http://video-drone.diy3dtech.com/high-intensity-cree-led-white-strobe-light-for-drones/

Major Favor: if you make one of these please post the Make and share it with the community :-) .

In addition, this was Printed on a Tronxy X5S printer from Gearbest (see more here: http://diy3dtech.com/gearbest-tronxy-x5s-high-precision-large-scale-3d-printer/ ) using black PLA.

Also, please follow us on Thingiverse and give this a like if this came in handy and for more information on this project, please visit us at http://www.DIY3DTech.com as well as subscribe to our YouTube Channel at http://YouTube.DIY3DTech.com along with a visit to our drone site and YouTube channel at http://video-drone.DIY3DTech.com

If you are looking for one of a kind swag shop for yourself or a Maker Geek friend, visit our swag shop at http://Swag.DIY3DTech.com for unique 3D Printing, Laser Cutting and CNC swag! Too, if you want a behind the scene look at what we are working on be sure to follow us on Instagram (https://www.instagram.com/diy3dtech/)!

description.text:
I modeled this thing to replace broken original Hebe TITAN II vapour mouthpiece.
I have seen 2 of them both having mouthpiece broken at the same place.
I have measured and modeled the original part geometry.
Then I made few variants how to make this part more stronger and solid in weak place.

Notes:

I did not print it yet.
I think 0.2mm layer with 40+ %infill and 3+ perimeter.
It can be printed with supports but I think it is better to print it upside down so the working/connecting planes will be more finished.

Front cover for the Ultimaker 3 Extended. Designed for .093” thick Plexiglas or lexan. I do not know the opening dimensions for the regular Ultimaker 3 for cutting the Plexiglas/lexan. I imagine 100mm less in length would work.
When not in use, the cover can hang on the side of the machine.
Note: Custom text will be added upon request, just ask.

Materials needed:
1) Printed: Top 1.stl
2) Printed: Top 2.stl
3) Printed: Bottom 3.stl
4) Printed: Bottom 3.stl
5) Sheet of .093” thick Plexiglass or Lexan 11” x 16 5/8”
6) Super Glue, Gel type works well
7) ¼” drill bit, small pilot drill recommended.
8) Sand Paper, 220 or 320 grit if needed

Assembly Steps:
1) Print the top and bottom pieces.
2) Sand and check fits if needed.
3) Cut and drill Plexiglas/lexan as shown.
4) Insert and glue the “bottom 1” piece to the glass, note orientation in image.
5) Assemble and glue the “bottom 2” piece to the other side of the glass, note orientation in image.
6) Glue “top 1” and “top2” pieces together, note orientation in image.
7) Glue top pieces to the glass with pegs inserted into the drilled holes on the glass.
8) Hang cover onto the machine and center it over the opening.
9) Mark the top screw locations on the glass.
10) Drill ¼” holes for clearance of the screws.

this was one of my first models i made i thought i would start out with something easy and yet i learned alot from this model. now i have nothing to do with the company that makes kan jam but seriously thought this item should exist so in the amazing world of 3d printing... if you can dream it and design it, it can be yours. and there is nothing more that goes with a good game of kan jam then a cold beer and since even when we set our beers down ten feet away from the kan it never fails that someones beer gets hit with a wild frisbee throw. so why not give em more of an excuse to hit it anyways. haha. so i know the model isnt perfect with the font placement and style i think it still is a big accomplishment for me for never making anything on a computer at all besides in microsoft paint so over all i am happy with it. the can fits down inside with almost no gaps and i tried to print with no supports but the slot in the front wouldnt come out. also my actual picture has a bit of issues with the print but that was just because i didnt want to wait long for the prototype to print so i cranked up the speed. also i printed in white pla and just sprayed it black then came back with a paint brush and went over the lettering. i hope you enjoy this print and if you decide to make one please let me know. and also let me know what you think and if you feel i deserve it go ahead and leave a tip. thanks a bunch for checking it out i hope to release more of my own ideas in the future.

After printing, you'll need to break-loose the hinge attaching the strap to the bar. The capo will work as printed, but putting a small piece of closed-cell foam (weather stripping works well) on the strap will protect your neck's finish and also make it easier to get the right pressure on the strings. Putting a thin strip of electrical tape on the bar where it contacts the strings will help keep it from sliding around if you bump it.

description.text:
made thing shaving bowl.

it's hollow, so that you can fill the area between the outer layer and the inner layer with hot water, and have nice, hot lather for shaving.

the outer and inner layers are pretty thin, 1.2mm, so it should be printed with enough "outer layers" to make that 100%. infill should be at least 15%, because there is some kind of a column holding between the bottom of the outer layer and the bottom of the inner layer, (the only hollow part) that needs at least 15% to be able to have a nice inner bottom (no sagging because of bridging).

could be printed in PLA, but be careful how hot your water is or else your bowl might become soft and malleable. ABS would be perfect for pretty much any hot tap water.

If you like it, like it. if you make it post a made it (REALLY), and comment on how good (or bad) it is... thanks!

this was inspired by https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1634087

PS: simplify3d has a hard time with this part, it closes up the spout. CURA pruduces it perfect. I'm not certain about other slicers. but don't use simplify3d, or at least not without inspecting the sliced part first.

description.text:
Refer to the pdf file..

IMPROVEMENT ON THE FILAMENT SENSOR FEEDING

The original design for the filament sensor holding mechanism was not a good idea. The filament is bend during the feeding & when filament is retracting during the no extrusion print, the filament will push back about 10mm drop. The filament will need space to move downward. At that point, the magnet holder will be bent even more thus creating some sound as it is limited to the space available to move.

In-order to better secure the position, I have come out a bracket/holder to hold the filament sensors. It will be a easy fix with one screw.

Remove the Round magnet from the filament sensor. (Keep it)
Remove the magnet holder (Keep it) from the printer frame using the allen key. Keep the screw for the new bracket.

3) Position the bracket to align the sensor as well as the mounting hole. Use the allen key to go thru the hole for tightening.

4) Once tighten, reposition the sensor so that it will align with the extractor base. It should be exactly inline.

After this do a test print to see if it moves correctly. If necessary, the groove may be smoothen by sandpaper…

Watch the sensor guide in operation: https://goo.gl/be4RZ8

You may want to also take a look at another household item design.
Spool Cap
https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2569210

Small Sander
https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2611160

Myself
"I make a living creating useful stuffs to help people around the world. If you like my free 3d projects, consider supporting me by tip option or paypal donation to [email protected] Much Appreciated."

title: Large lock-pick handle (designed for Sparrows picks)

description.text: I have large hands and I find large handles easier to manage(XL glove size). I started out with designing a handle for wiper blade inserts, but now that I have purchased some sparrow picks, I modified my design to fit them. This handle is designed to be printed in two halves, then glued together with epoxy. It has gone through several revisions. I started by forming a comfortable handle with moldable plastic to my hands. I drew up the first version and it became my favorite pick. For this version I slimmed it down slightly. I have intentionally left the corners un-rounded and allowed the circles to stretch past the edges in order to add a better tactile feel to them (you can tell their orientation by touch alone). I plan to also try dipping these in plasti-dip once assembled, but they seem comfortable enough the way they are. Please feel free to modify as I have included the original Sketchup file. I don't have time to make custom adjustments for people.

title: Flyfun V5 160A HV Opto fan mount

description.text: Fan mount for Hobbywing Flyfun V5 160A and 130A HV OPTO ESCs. Designed for use with a 40mm Hobbywing Platinum V4 fan but should work with any 40mm fan that has 32mm mounting hole spacing. With Hobbywing fan M3 14mm screws are used other fans may need differing lenght screws. Check to make sure the screws do not interfere with the heatsink on the ESC. M3 nylock nuts are interference fit and install permanently into the holes (tighten the screw to pull the nut into the hole). There are three different versions of the fan mount, one with countersink screws that install from the bottom to be attached to a surface with double back adhesive tape, one with plain through holes where the ESC and fan mount are both screwed down to the mounting surface and a version for the Rush 750 (or any heli with a 46mm wide frame). On the countersink and Rush versions of the ESC mount you will need a small adjustable wrench to hold the nylock nuts in place at the battery end as there is not enough clearance between the nut and the side of the ESC for a nut driver there.

description.text:
The 4 caps of our family's Cricket Cage broke. We taped them for a while and were going to use glue to fix them, but then we had a thought about making them better redesigning them. We used digital calipers to measure the existing tubes for the diameter, depth, and wall thickness.

This could be adapted for any home school project for pets in a one off manufacturing process. Connect this with Measurement & Data Common Core Standards - http://www.corestandards.org/Math/Content/MD/
CCSS

Introduction This was used in our family to show the basics of 3D modeling and design. It provided good practice with using and reading a digital caliper. This could be adapted to an item that is really a one off manufactured part and something that is not an "off the shelf product." This provides a good discussion about Product Design, Materials, and Recycling. This could expand into a week long exploration into Product Design if it is linked to the documentary Objectified - http://www.hustwit.com/category/objectified/ I have no connection to this movie, the producers, or director. It is a good starting point for discussions about the objects all around us.

Steps

  • Have students find a simple part. This means a part that does not have too many internal openings, overhangs, or shifts directions. Items that follow basic squares, rectangles, circles are good. This cap was really a cylinder and easy to measure. This could be done in the classroom or at home. Preferably it is an item that is broken and a 3D printed part would be a good, practical example of home manufacturing.

  • Have students measure the object with digital calipers. If the object is complex, you could place the object on top of a flatbed scanner and scan the object. Another option is laying the object next to a ruler (mm or in) and take a photo of it. Sketchup allows you to SCALE the model based on a known dimension. Just make sure that the model only contains the object you wish to scale because this feature will scale up everything in the Sketchup model.

  • Students can build the model in Sketchup. They may need some training in this software. There are many great videos and online tutorials to reference.

  • Have students learn the process of "measure twice, cut once," which means in the digital world, measure twice to double check dimensions. Also have them practice their skills of observation to verify that the object on the screen looks like the actual product.

  • Have the students print the file. The "prototype" might not fit perfectly. Make sure that students are prepped for this disappointment. As Mythbuster's Adam Savage always said "failure is always an option." https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=i5sbUi3_w3w In the world of 3D printing, it happens. Things need to be remeasured. Materials and machine variations have different tolerances. This is a good discussion for the group in how to consider tolerance into their digital designs.

  • Have the students create a digital slideshow of their parts and present them to the class. They could provide the reasons they chose the part and what challenges they had in the 3D modeling process.

Materials Neeed
  • Sketchup Make
  • Digital Calipers
  • An object that has a function (caps, boxes, cases)

comments.text: Looks great! I wanted to offer other angles, but got busy with other projects. Did you have to lower the mounting hole any to make the camera clear the top plate? I have it slammed to the top pretty tight to provide the most clearance between the camera connector and flight stack when using 30x30 components.
comments.author: Quad_Logic

comments.text: Ah, I printed a 20x20 to 30x30 adapter and used 20x20 components.  So my camera fits nicely on my quad with the smaller FC and AIO ESC.  The camera is a little high though and you can see the front prongs of the frame in the camera view, but I don't mind.  Adds character and doesn't effect flying.  Thanks again for making the original!
comments.author: Quad_Logic

comments.text: Hey no problem! I love sharing ideas that work out lol. I've noticed something odd with the Shrieker frames though, some have 30x30 and 20x20 holes while some just have 30x30 holes. I've built a couple with 20x20 components and I just printed a drill guide and drilled my own holes as needed. On seeing the horns on the top plate, I actually use a dremel and cut mine back a couple millimeters while following the original curve so you don't even notice it's done when looking at the quad. The one in my pictures is done that way. It doesn't get rid of them 100%, but it helps. And I'm not sure if you could lower the cam enough to get rid of them anyway, especially with a 2.1 lens and a 25mm deck height. But I'm with you, I think it adds character to the flying experience. I really enjoy mine.

title: Adjustable Titan Aero Mirrored Mount Aurora A3 (and other i3 clones)

description.text:
Remixed the awesome Original Prusa i3 MK2 E3D Titan Aero Upgrade by GregoryHolloway for my Aurora A3 i3 clone.

This is a z-height adjustable mount for the E3D Titan Aero extruder. Found that with the new extruder, no mount would work on my tall setup, and I occasionally like to try new bed setups, so an adjustable z-height would be useful. Requires a few M3 bolts and nuts to assemble. Pretty easy to figure out where they go.

I have a mirrored setup, so I had to redesign the part cooling fan accordingly. The cooling duct should work on the original mount by Gregory.

The cooling duct also has a mounting point for the cable chains here: https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:611593

I also moved the x-limit switch to the carriage assembly, but that part isn't ready for prime-time yet.

Included the Fusion360 step file for further remixing.

author: AlphaSquadMultirotor

description.text:
Scans and STLs of some barnacles found on a Seattle beach.
I can't quite say why, but lately I've been interested in barnacles, so I decided to stop off at the beach and scan a few.  The results are uploaded here.
Personally, I think the best use for these - apart from admiring their form - is to carry a pocketful and some double-sided tape and stick them tastefully on doorways and secluded corners as you go about your everyday affairs.  Eventually others will notice and wonder what the devil is going on - it'll add a nice air of mystery and romance to the landscape and enhance the contrasting lines of the inorganic structures we deal with every day.
WARNING: sticking them to objects you don't own may be considered graffiti or vandalism, so proceed with caution and don't break the law.
I have also included the original scans - feel free to make your own versions or incorporate these into some other project.  A barnacle encrusted Colbert, for example.

1: Print as many as you like.
2: Stick to whatever objects you please.
3: Post or link to pictures.
4: Be respectful of other people's property in general.

comments.text:
YES! I was thinking about 3dprinted barnacles as a guerrilla public art project and wondered if anyone had scanned barnacles...
And here we are.

title: T-Rex Skeleton Femur Adjustment for different stance

description.text:
I wanted the T-Rex to be able to stand on its own feet without supports, and also give it a more realistic stance.
Most of the changes I could do by bending the printed parts in hot water and hotglueing them slightly different.
There was one part (femur of right leg) that I could not "correct" with these previous ways, so some STL modification was needed. I used blender for this.

Disclaimer: my blender modeling skills are not so great, so this model is purely functional and needs hotglue to attach it to the rest of the skeleton.

Dont make your first layer too thick and do not use too high temp ... otherwise the embossed characters (which are quite delicate already) on the back will turn out too thin.

author: 3dexter10

title: 2X Extruder Upgrade for Raffle Alu-Dual Cooling Block
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
I recently installed one of Carl Raffle's cooling block upgrades (http://shop.raffle.ch/) on my 2X and rather than use a shim I modded rmcniff's very nice extruder. Between Carl's block and rmcniff's extruder I have been able to print PLA on my 2X for the first time ever. Changes from original version:
  • Subtracted 3mm from back of base which aligns feed holes with Carl's block.
  • Added screw mount for bearing.
  • Removed recess for thermal barrier so filament is guided the whole way to cooling block. (I installed barriers flush with top of block).
  • Removed outer spring brace to allow easier access and installation of spring.

Everything has been run through netfabb and is ready to go. I printed mine in ABS with 2 shells and 50% fill and supports (only for underside of base). Seems good so far. You will need:
  • From original extruders: bearing & shoulder bolt.
  • M4 x 10-12mm flathead or #8 x 3/8 - 1/2" (For bearing)
  • M3 x 5-8mm flathead for attaching base to motor
  • Spring - I used rmcniff's suggestion: http://www.mcmaster.com/#1986k5/=qtpbwl
    • Rather than repeat rmcniff's excellent directions:
    http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:222667/#instructions

comments.text: Do you think it's a bad idea to print this out in PLA? Would it grip the filament too much if slightly heated? Is it even strong enough if printed in PLA?
comments.author: RobertPaul

comments.text: I don't think PLA will hold up to the stress and heat.
comments.author: RobertPaul

comments.text: I installed it without the upper nut, however because the nozzles are now lower, they scrape the build plate. Even when I bottom out the screws when leveling the build plate, it's still an issue. Do you have solidworks files that I could modify ?
comments.author: orivier

comments.text: I directly modified the STL's so no CAD files.  The best I could do are OBJ files if that helps.
comments.author: orivier

comments.text: Question : If you omitted the upper nut, how did you fixed the threaded thermal barrier ?
comments.author: eosbandi

comments.text: I'm just using the nut on the bottom of the block, if tightened up well everything stays in place fine.
comments.author: eosbandi

comments.text: By directly attaching to extruder to the cooling block, you are adding all the stepper motor heat to the block as well.  Are you sure you want to do that?  Seems like adding the plastic shim will "mostly" insulate the stepper heat from the bar and give you even more robust PLA feeding.
comments.author: dssguy1

comments.text: Hasn't been a problem.  The Thing-o-matic and other early printers were setup the same way and print PLA fine.  It's the threaded thermal barriers vs. the clamped-in ones that makes the difference.
comments.author: dssguy1

comments.text: So glad I clicked on this, I'm going to order Mr. Raffle's upgrades as soon as I can.  Thank you for the link.

Scanned with MakerBot Digitizer - triple scan.  Piece from a complete set originally scanned by the National Museums of Scotland and reproduced in resin from the ancient originals. Fausse pile AA

Translation at the bottom of the page
https://youtu.be/Gk2qYdwFriE

Caractéristiques :

  • Élément qui se positionne en lieu et place d'une pile AA, permet d'utiliser un   bloc pile AA  surdimensionné et de réduire le nombre de piles (la tension) à son besoin.

  • La continuité électrique est assurée de préférence par deux « attaches parisiennes » à positionner dans les deux extrémités et à souder ensemble.
    La continuité électrique peut aussi être réalisée par deux vis conductrices (de 3 à 3,5 mm de diamètre , épaisseur tête de 2 mm) reliées par un conducteur électrique de diamètre proche de1 mm, le fil peut être enroulé autour de la tête de vis, voir suivant les cas souder au niveau de la pointe de vis.

Vérifier la continuité électrique et la longueur de la fausse pile qui doit être proche de 50,5 mm (voir vidéo )
////////////////////////////
Characteristics :

  • Element that is positioned instead of an AA battery, allows use of an oversized AA battery pack and reduces the number of batteries (voltage) to its need.

  • Electrical continuity is ensured preferably by two "Parisian fasteners" to be positioned in both ends and welded together.
    Electrical continuity can also be achieved by two conductive screws (3 to 3.5 mm in diameter, head thickness 2 mm) connected by an electrical conductor with a diameter close to 1 mm, the wire can be wound around the screw head , see below welding at the tip of the screw.

Check the electrical continuity and length of the false battery, which should be close to 50.5 mm (see video)

Though I`m a Novice I decided to build my own custom 3D printer from scratch. There were no parts in Thingiverse that I needed thus have to design my own.

comments.text: Does this actually work? I mean, the plot seems to indicate that it's going to be close enough to autotune, but does it receive anything usefully?
comments.author: teamwija

comments.text:
Yes, it works.
As small frame antenna, it's not as sensitive as a dipole, but as it's narrow band, it picks less noise.
comments.author: teamwija

comments.text: What makes it not suitable for transmission? Is it just a really poor match?
comments.author: dhg864

comments.text:
As it's a passive antenna, you can transmit if you want - it's like a multi turn magnetic loop. But there are a few things you must take care of:
1) The match is not good, So you have to experiment with the coupling loop (make it smaller, ...)
2) The "capacitor" will only withstand small voltages. So I would expect more than 1W will create isolation issues.
3) The radiator is very thin and has a high resistance. Also multi turn will reduce the effective surface.
This all will lead to an effectiveness like a wet rope :-)
I would suggest, you build a Magnetic Loop with a Delta match from e.g. RG213. A capacitor for mono band, you can also use RG213 (100pF per Meter) or even in split configuration. This will withstand about 3kV.

description.text:
12/26/17 Added edge guide to drill guide.

12/18/17 Replaced corner braces and rear y-rod holders with mirrored pairs. Rplaced Rambo adapter (attaches RAMBO case to extrusion for stiffness) and PSU (fits clone) with versions with slotted screw hols for extrusion attachment.

12/17/17 updated drill guide to Mk3 spacing. Replaced RAMBO case with new cable grips (use mk2.5 covers). Do NOT use y-idler until re-done as the lenght is wrong compared to the Mk3 version.

10/26/17 modified belt holder to allow bed to go back fully. Rear extrusion should have been 5mm longer and front ones shorter. clone is assembled and passed self-test.

10/22/17 files refreshed

This started as a cost saving alternative to the Haribo/Zaribo mods. The intension was to re-use as much as possible of the MK2 while discarding the allthread. Then the MK3 came out and I modified my design to follow his. This is in no way official!!! This is stricltly my version. The parts have only been tested on a clone frame at this point. The RAMBo case is a solif case with a removalble panel door and a separate brace that attaches to the extrusion. It is totally optional. My PSU case is for a different PSU and may not fit the Prusa PSU (not tested) but it should be trivial to modify his to attach to the extrusion. I will upload extrusion lengths later.

It should be possible to use the drilling guide with all MK3 parts if you download the DXF files for the front and back plates, print them at 1:1 and glue that to steel as a cutting/drilling guide. If you go that route use the Prusa supplied lengths for the extrusions. Hole sizes are 3.1mm (1/8") and 5.1mm (3/16"). https://github.com/prusa3d/Original-Prusa-i3/tree/MK3/Frame

Printer:

Genuine Prusa MK2(s)

Rafts:

No

Resolution:

normal or optimum

Infill:

varies

Notes:

A few pieces need support, should be obvious. I have included designed in supports in several cases

Drill guide

Use the guide to drill holes for M5 screws to attach the extrusions to the frame. Insert the raised portion into the notch and align the guide to the frame. Clamp tightly. Ude a 5mm drill bit but do not attempt to drill the hole completely. The heat of friction and the metal waste can damage the guide and it is needed to drill both sides. Drill just deep enough to produce a start hole so the bit does not shift when finishing the hole. About 1 mm is sufficient. You will have to move the clamp during the process so it is a good idea to have two clamps on hand.

Brackets and feet

There are two bracket STLs - one with and one without feet. They are designed to mount on the bottom and connect two extrusions. I purchased EVERBILT Threaded Stem Glides at my local HomeDepot. They have a 1/4" stem which will cut threads in the hole provided. A nut catch is provided, but it is metric and too small for SAE 1/4" nuts. An optional separate foot is provided for three footed configurations if desired. The brackets can be arranged with the feet either to the side or end positions. Some elevation is needed to raise the frame off of the table or the printer will rock on the frame. The feet mentioned are felt bottomed, but hard rubber feet are also available and vibration adsorbtive pads could be attached directly to the printed foot.

Be sure to insert any nuts and guides in the side rails before connecting end rails.

Rear motor mount and rod guides

These parts are designed to mount to an extrusion across the rear. Slide catches will hold them to the extrusion while being set in place and held with a screw and nut. The motor mount is of a three hole design and will also hold the Y endstop.

Extrusions

3030 extrusions: per Mk3 spec
Front side rails - 2pc 205mm. 4.2 mm holes (one end) tap 20 mm deep with M5
Rear side rails - 2pc 120mm 4.2 mm holes (one end) tap 20 mm deep with M5

These need to be adjusted for the fact that this mod uses extrusion rather than plates on the front and back . My side rails are 100mm and 197mm.

front rail - 1pc 200mm
rear rail - 1pc 274mm
Extrusion Nuts and screws - 21 each
M5 button head socket screws - 12 - 16 mm - 16ea.

description.text:
This is a stand with a few helping hands to support working on small parts such as PCBs or multirotor helicopters. Mount points for the coolant pipes have been 3D printed.

The original idea has been featured on hackaday. However, I had a wooden base and some different tools than mentioned in the article. So, this is the design I ended up with.

I used 3.5mm x 20mm TORX wood screws to mount the printed parts on the base. Other parts required for building this tool like coolant pipes and alligator clips can easily be found on aliexpress and other similar websites. It simply does not pay to print these. In total this project cost me around 10$.

My git repository containing the sources of all my 3D-parts and designs can be found here: https://github.com/rpoisel/3d-parts

title: Spool Holder Mount for Prusa i3

description.text:
This mount along with spool holder designed by RamonSeda, titled "2020 UNIVERSAL SPOOL HOLDER", will replace the spool holder came with my original Purse i3 MK2. The link is below (but I've include the needed files here):

https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1860430/#files

RamonSeda designed the spool holder to be mounted on 2020 aluminum extrusion, but with this mount, you will be able to slide and lock the holder on the top, right corner of the Prusa i3 frame. It will not obstruct the printer's operation. I also like this design because less filament bending from spool holder to extruder.

Besides printing one of each STL files, you will need:

2 608zz bearings
4 M8 nuts (Use 2 on each end to lock the nuts)
1 M8 threaded rod at least 15cm long (17 cm is OK and easier to work with)

CAUTION!! If you cut M8 threaded rod, make sure you screw in the nuts first. Because if you damage the thread, it would be difficult to threaded in further. Do check out some video about cutting threaded rod first.

title: Circle Cutting Jig for plunge router

description.text:
This was designed for a project where I need to cut loads of holes out of wood with a plunge router.
The idea is it hooks into 2 pieces of m8 threaded rod, which fits into the guide holes in the router.

Design files are now available on github https://github.com/thinkl33t/Things/tree/master/Circle%20Cutting%20Jig
  • You may need to adjust the parameters and re-render the scad file before printing, the attached STL is for my router, which has 8mm holes that are 84mm apart.
  • Print
  • Fix a 608 bearing in the central bearing hole, and fit the central piece through the middle of it.
  • Attach two pieces of M8 threaded rod through the 8mm Holes, and bolt on both sides.
  • Insert the threaded rod into the guide holes in the router. the distance between the central hole and the inside of the router bit is the radius of your hole.
  • Put a screw through the central piece and into the center point of the piece you are cutting, and cut!

author: GRay_111111

description.text: Parametric microphone shock-mount.

I designed this parametric shockmount for my Neumann KM183/184 microphones. The values given and the STL files are for these microphones. I used thick elastic bands for your hair and added a clip to make sure that the microphone will not drop when tilting the shockmount. I printed it with 5/8" 27TPI thread in the mount hole and added a metal adapter because I was afraid that the plastic would not be strong enough to survive multiple mounts/removals.

It is easy to change for your own microphone. All the parameters are in the first part of the OpenSCAD files. You can choose whether you want no holes in the side, two or three holes. You can choose different threads or no thread for the mount hole. Beware: to get nicely rounded corners you will need to choose lower values for $fa and $fs, but this takes a long time to render (like half an hour or more). Because of this, the STL file for the shock-mount is big.

Note that it is a shock-mount for straight microphone types (not for the microphones that are used for singers in studios). If there are people who want to use it for e.g. a Shure Beta I am willing to make a version that has different grooves at the two ends to accomodate this.

Update 2017-10-10:
I added an STL file that is meant to be printed with TPU and 10% infill.
It makes for a more flexible clip. To generate it yourself use the following in the scad file:
dic = 27.0;
dsh = 0;
wco = 17.0;

title: Runcam Micro Swift 2 mount for Eachine Racer 130

description.text:
A mount designed to fit the Eachine Racer 130 and Runcam Micro Swift 2. Based on the size of the camera it ended up only fitting with a 30 degree uptilt. If you modified the frame, or extended the standoffs you could get a different tilt.

For screws I used some longer m2*7mm screws that came with some extra props. The existing m2 screws don't have enough thread to grab the plastic, but the 7mm long ones seem to work fine.

Printed in PLA, needs some support because of the chin that extends beyond the frame. Prints in about 20 minutes.

title: BLV mgn12 mod for Anet A8 / AM8 / Prusa I3 clone
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
BLV mgn12 mod for Anet A8 / AM8

  • The main purpose of this project is: converting your Anet A8 into an incredible 3d printer, using MGN12 rails fixed on an aluminium extrusion frame.

  • This upgrade compatible with pheneeny's AM8 mod with small changes. (Huge credit!)

  • Why mgn?
    The linear bearing and Delrin Wheel Gantry commonly used at most of low-mid 3d printers as a cheaper solution for linear motion. Its cheaper replacement for the expensive mgn rails BUT price is at the expense of accuracy and reliability. Well, linear guided rails (mgn rails) are much more rigid, extreme precise and smooth then linear bearing or Delrin. The linear rails lets you print with higher speed - shorting print time without compromising print quality. The fact rails are fixed to frame prevents unwanted motion related to bent threaded rods or other axis's motion. There seems to be a good reason why they are mostly used with high end 3d printers..
    So, i found cheap chinese mgn rails at Aliexpress and thought to myself why not?

IMPORTANT

fixing the mgn rails can be very frustrating. it need to be perfectly aligned and straight.
else, it will give you a headache, so don't start this project without tons of patience.

  • design flexibility and Source file
    I'm sharing with you the source file of this project in order to improve the design and make it even more better. you will find the STEP file inside the project zip.
    Please follow the item license (under the Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike.).

  • If you are using the STEP file, please don't forget to mark it as a Remix :)

  • Also made for this project a Build plate for simplify3d

Please notice you may need to re-center bed coordinates via marlin configuration
or change Z extrusion position to center the hotbed

Build it at your own risk.

Latest video update
A quick peek at my project building progress.
sorry for all the exposed wires - i had to test it. first video after all axis's electronics had been connected. Next week i'll get the 400mm threaded rods and install the rest.
I had to reverse x-motor connector in this video beacuse mistakly i fixed the carriage screw on the back instead on the front (i fixed and uploaded the fixed x carriage).

  • Seeing all of this great community members uploading photos and remixes worth all of the long hours that i have put into this project :)
    I will appreciate if you could please upload an "I made one" photos :)
    Thank you guys !!!

• 3/2/18 Added a PDF file with all the offset measurements for Hotend and sensors.
  • 7/1/18 All STEP files updated including: Main Printer, Cube carriage and MK3 carriage.
    (If you are using it, i will appreciate if you could please mark it as a REMIX)
  • 6/1/18 New experimental Cube carriage supports V6/Clone BLtouch, 8mm/12mm Sensor (required 4010 blower fan). (inspired by CR-10)
  • 6/1/18 New MK3 carriage made for Prusa original MK3 nuzzle fan support BLtouch, 8mm/12mm Sensor. I Love this Carriage !!
  • 6/1/18 New X-screw holder extended
  • 6/1/18 New holders made for 30A/29A 360W power supply.
  • 6/1/18 New X motor holder added a 4010 fan holder to cool the X motor on higher speeds.
  • 6/1/18 New 4010 Spitfire style fan cover for the New X motor holder.
  • 6/1/18 Modified the rear corners which allows threading cables through extrusions.
  • 8.12/17 improved bed adapters for better slicing process.
  • 25/11/17 added 2 type of Jigs that helps aligning the mgn12 rails
  • 17/11/17 added a new experimental carriage adapter for Anet A8 Original carriage
    STEP file updated ! (can be edited with any CAD software exp: fusion360)
    added X-motor cover+cable holder (infill 65%+)
  • 05/11 added X-Carriage for E3D Chimera Hotend
  • 02/11 new LED strip holder (compatible with regular 9.8mm strip width)
    new rubber feet mount instead of the tapped method. (Print with 60% infill)
    new improved X-Carriage (added on both sides cable holder)
  • 28/10 BOM updated
  • 27/10 added Heated bed Belt locker (belt_lock_infill80.stl) (infill 80%+)
  • 26/10 fixed x-carriage (the belt holder holes are now on front - reveres x motor not needed any more)
  • 23/10 BOM list updated (added solution for AM8 with 440mm z extrusion)
  • 22/10 added Cad Source file due to community request (BLV Mgn12 mod.step).
    added BOM file (pdf)
    added printing orientation images
Quick video: It's alive :) the first axis test..

Mod variations:

You have the ability to choose your own style:

  1. Anet A8 converted to AM8 (original height: 440mm)+ BLV mgn12 mod:
    If you are already a proud owner of an AM8 printer and don't want to change the orignal height, you will have to get a 350mm rails instead of 400mm .

  2. Anet A8 converted to AM8 + Higher Z-axis (height: 500mm) + BLV mgn12 mod:
    First you will have to build an AM8 with a small changes:

    • instead of: 2x440mm 2040 extrusion > replace with: 2x500mm 2040 extrusion or bigger.
    • instead of: 2x340mm 2040 extrusion > replace with: 4x364mm 2040 extrusion
    • get a longer threaded rods 400mm.
      obviously, you don't need to print all AM8 parts but some (more info at printing info section)
  3. Anet AM8 + Free style + BLV mgn12 mod:
    As i mentioned, the design is flexible and includes separated parts that can be fitted to your wish. if you want custom size printer with a bigger bed or higher Z-axis, please choose wisely your own extrusion size and attached the modular parts to your desired extrusion.

Requirements:
  1. Anet A8 printer > AM8
  2. Tools
  3. Technical ability
  4. spare time
BOM - parts you need

clarification: BOM includes AM8 BOM.

  • 7 x Mgn12H Carriage (4 for Y-axis, 1 for X-axis, 2 for Z axis)
  • 3 x 2040 extrusion 313mm (for top, front, back)
  • 4 x 2040 extrusion 364mm (Y-axis)
  • 1 x 2020 extrusion 420mm (x-axis)
  • 2 x 608zz bearing (optional: if you intend using the top threaded rod holders)
  • 16 x HBLFSNF5 Corner Bracket
  • 150 x M5X10 Button Head Socket Cap Screw
  • 8 x M5x10 Socket Head Cap Screw
  • 6 x M5x16 Socket Head Cap Screw
  • 4 x M3X20 Socket Head Cap Screw
  • 60 x M3X8 Socket Head Cap Screw
  • 1 x M4X30 hex head (y-tensioner button)
  • 6 x M3X20 screw
  • 1 x M3X32 screw
  • 20 x M4X10 screw
  • 160 x M5 T-nut or M5x.8 Square Nut
  • 40 x M3 T-nut
  • 4 x M3 nut
  • 13 x M3 Washer
  • 1 x M3 nylock
  • 20 x M4 nut
  • 20 x M4 washer
  • 6 x Rubber Feet
  • 2 x GT2 16T idler (3mm bore)
  • 1 x 5 meters GT2 reinforced fiberglass belt 6mm wide pitch 2mm
  • 1 x PC4-M6 OD4mm (optional: if using greg's geard extruder)

for option 1 (original AM8 size):

  • 2 x 2040 extrusion 440mm (z axis)
  • 3 x Mgn12 350mm rail (x & z axis)
  • 2 x Mgn12 400mm rail (y axis)

for option 2 (extended z height):

  • 4 x Mgn12 400mm rail
  • 1 x Mgn12 360mm or 350mm rail
  • 2 x 2040 extrusion 500mm (z axis)
  • 2 x Threaded Rods 400mm
Additional electronics BOM
  • 1 x e3d v6 hotend or Clone
    Or
  • 1 x e3d Chimera hot end

Part to print from this BLV mgn12 mod project:
print all except those optional parts:

  • Y mount motor - (print this part only if you dont have the AM8 Y motor mount)
  • Top z holders - (aka anti z-wobble) (holders may limit Z height and they are not really needed)
  • Caliper Holder - (print only if you have a digital metal caliper)
  • LCD case and brackets - (print it only if you have a reprap Discount LCD 12864 only, else use the original AM8 lcd case and brackets)

Part to print from AM8:

  • 1 x 1_LCD_Base_Left (only if you are planing to use the original Anet A8 lcd)
  • 1 x 1_LCD_Base_Right (only if you are planing to use the original Anet A8 lcd)
  • 1 x 1_LCD_Case_Top (only if you are planing to use the original Anet A8 lcd)
  • 1 x 1_PSU_Mount (for Original Anet PSU)
  • 1 x 1_Wire_Holder
  • 2 x 2_Bottom_Tee_Plate
  • 2 x 2_Top_Corner_Plate
  • 4 x 4_Bottom_Corner_Plate
  • 1 x Anet_Board_Mount__With_Fan (dont print if you choose the electronics box)
    OR
  • 1 x Anet_Board_Mount_No_Fan (dont print if you choose the electronics box)
Material and Infill

Inside zip file you will find a PDF file named: BLV mgn12 mod.pdf
which contain full spec of the Parts (name, material to print with and infill percentage).

Printing orientation

Highly important: i added 4 pictures showing printing orientation of the prats.
the printing orientation is very important because it contributes to the strength of the items.

  • make sure before printing that its calibrated since the dimension precision are crucial !
view original size: open it in a new windows and save the image or use the pdf file inside the zip files view original size: open it in a new windows and save the image or use the pdf file inside the zip files

1. Assemble the frame extrusion according to pheneeny's AM8 mod
    at the AM8 mod files you will find also the prefect guide pheneeny made for assemby.

  2. Assemble the BLV mgn12 mod according to assembly instructions that found in this project zip file. its a pdf file named:BLV mgn12 mod.pdf. the file contains sketch with all
    the main parts.

  3. I made an assembly video in order to explain how to assemble: Bed adapters, X-axis components, Cube carriage and V6 carriage. On this video i mentioned a 5010 blower fan but i was wrong- I meant for 5015 fan (Thank you Craig).
    Please notice you may need re-center the hotend/bed coordinates via marlin configuration.

Additional Optional Parts
  • Greg's geard extruder
  • Build plate of this project for simplify3d available here
  • Radial Fan Fang (including sensors adapters)
  • CPT_Spekkie AM8 Electronics Case
  • Devin's Knob with fine tuning dial
  • PapaJohn88's mount for Anet A6 lcd (rec by artistebot)
  • Handle For AM8

MGN Rails

Well, i used a cheap Chinese mgn12 rails from aliexpress cost 20$ each.
The store i bought it from named: "Mellow" via aliexpress. Before that i bought from other store named: "linkcnc Store" and the rails was awful! it was a used rails, damaged and shorter then what i ordered. They ware so awful, that even after cleaning and lubricating it was still stuck and jammed.

Cleaning and lubricating

notice that the mgn rails you'll get will not be smooth as it should be.
at the factory they lubricate it with a protecting oil that need to be cleaned away.
There are some videos on YouTube showing how to clean the carriage with WD-40.
don't forget that after cleaning both rails and carriage, you will have to lubricate it with sewing machine oil.
As for smoothness: Please ignore the method for testing smoothness but tilting the rail - its wrong! You want it to be smooth but not too much.
Also, since its a miniature rails, please don't use thick grease to lubricate.

Adittional links

Cleaning mgn12 carriage video:
youtube.com/watch?v=luonzoH-xwQ
Although the video in russian language which i don't understand - its a pretty good video. just use a container in order not to lose steel balls

note: after assembling all steel balls, you will be left with empty space of one steel ball.

Rails installation:

INPORTANT

  • fixing the rail can very frustrating, you will have to re adjust it a few times until the rail will be leveled and straight.
  • the mgn bed adapters needs to be fixes with screws to the heated bead carriage - screws must be tighten in cross like in anet a8 manual.
  • take your time an adjust until it will be even from both sides then the motion will be smooth.
    its very tricky and need a lot of patience.

Note: The motor in the video is incompatible. it was installed only for taking the video and testing the weight. view original size: open it in a new windows and save the image or use the pdf file inside the zip files view original size: open it in a new windows and save the image or use the pdf file inside the zip files

comments.text:
You are right and i will explain it:
In the original AM8 BOM there are 2 Y-axis size 340mm which was wrong, since it was less then the original Anet A8 y-axis size. as a result the pause function didn't worked. So, Another user (ranita) suggested changing the Y-axis extrusion size to 364mm in order to gain back the lost 2cm. in conclusion, You will have to buy 4 x 364mm Y-axis extrusions. I apologize for the messy pdf, in this case i made there 2 images: the first 2 x 364mm extrusion is for the bed rails and from right you will see another sketch with another 2 x 364mm extrusions.
Yes, you will have no problem doing it with 500mm the measurements will be divided excluding the bed size (you may have need to change the bed coordinates in marlin) i will be glad to add the right measurement or code after you will finish it.
